subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: Even though I did not write the mail you are responding to, I would like to answer: When unit testing guis you need to get access to the components in the
messageBody:
Even though I did not write the mail you are responding to, I would like to
answer:

When unit testing guis you need to get access to the components in the
view. If you develop under Borlands tool, you get default access to the
graphical components on the protected level. As in VAJ the components are
private I have to use reflection to gain access to them.

However, I still prefer the VAJ approach to that of JBuilder, as I can
keep the test code in seperate package. But that is imo a matter of personal
preferences.

Toyin

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 2:54 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?


> Out of curiosity... What is the need for your tests to access
> package-protected information? Shouldn't the tests be testing the public
> interfaces of your objects?
>
> -Jason
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: dror2@... [mailto:dror2@...]
> Sent: Sunday, June 10, 2001 7:11 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
>
>
>
> We're just beginning to add JUnit testing into our codebase.
> We've decided to put JUnit test classes into the same package, but sepeate
> classes, all with proper names (e.g. MyClassTester)
> This way the test classes are capable of accessing all package-protected
> methods,
> and its relatively easy to remove the test classes from production JARs
> (either by
> filtering them out from a JAR, or by using a tool such as ANT which can
> exclude specific
> files from JARring by using a wildcard on their name.
>
>
>
> David Gardner <david_j_gardner@...>
> 08/06/2001 11:33
> Please respond to junit
>
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> cc:
> Subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
>
>
>
> Hi Steven,
>
> I am in a similar position as yourself. I have decided
> to go for the seperate directory structure. The last
> option about embedding the tests in the class may make
> the code basedifficult to manage. You will have to
> have all of the testing resources in your classpath on
> production etc which does not make much sense. There
> is a tool called ANT which we will be using to manage
> the codebase. You can get to build all the code run
> the tests and deploy to production all in one script.
> I really like Together J but I have started using
> netbeans. It's totally free which my boss likes alot.
> The module for junit in that will create a test class
> for each class that contains empty test methods. I am
> also considering a test sub directory in each package
> instead. I think the avoiding deployment of the tests
> to production makes sense.
>
> Cheers
>
> David
>
>
>
> --- Steven Webster <steven.webster@...>
> wrote:
> > I've inherited a huge codebase which I'll be taking
> > over development for; as soon as
> > possible, I want to put skeletal JUnit tests in
> > place for every class; as I perform
> > refactorings, and as I introduce new functionality,
> > my intention is to first flesh out
> > JUnit tests, before adding feature/refactoring.
> >
> > This raises several questions, most of all related
> > to what are the best practices
> > for keeping Unit Tests alongside code.
> >
> > Options as I see them:
> >
> > 1. A separate directory tree with a root note of
> > test, the package structure of
> > which reflects that of the codebase; keep the
> > tests completely isolated from
> > production code, the downside being that if I
> > refactor code around packages,
> > I have to remember to move tests as well;
> > also, removes my ability to test
> > private and protected methods..
> >
> > 2. A 'test' directory in each package of the
> > codebase, containing TestXXXX
> > classes; with a TestXXXX class for each XXXX
> > class in the package above.
> > Again, can't test public/protected methods,
> > and a little extra work is
> > required to remove tests from production code,
> > but not that much.
> >
> > 3. Actually make each class in the production
> > code it's own test, ie put the
> > JUnit testing code in the class itself. This
> > gives me access to protected
> > and private methods, AND makes it easy to
> > refactor and move tests around.
> > Another upside is that the JUnit plugin for
> > Together UML will create all
> > these test skeletons for me in this manner.
> > Downside (and I see it as a
> > pretty big downside) is that my JUnit tests
> > are all but impossible to remove
> > from my production code.
> >
> > Has anyone got any thoughts on this problem ?
> > Anyone been in a similar
> > situation, and got suggestions they could offer ?
> >
> > Cheers,
> >
> > Steven
> >
>
